column1: Huntington Beach is a seaside city in Orange County in Southern California
column2: located 35 miles (56 km) southeast of Downtown Los Angeles. The city is named after American businessman Henry E. Huntington. The population was 189
column4: making it the fourth most populous city in Orange County
column5: the most populous beach city in Orange County
column6: and the seventh most populous city in the Los Angeles-Long Beach-Anaheim
column7: CA Metropolitan Statistical Area. Its estimated 2019 population was 199
column8: 223. It is bordered by Bolsa Chica Basin State Marine Conservation Area on the west
column9: the Pacific Ocean on the southwest
column10: by Seal Beach on the northwest
column12: by Fountain Valley on the northeast
column13: by Costa Mesa on the east
column14: and by Newport Beach on the southeast.

column1: Huntington Beach is known for its long 9.5-mile (15.3 km) stretch of sandy beach
column4: and beach culture. The ocean waves are enhanced by a natural effect caused by the edge-diffraction of open ocean swells around Santa Catalina Island. Swells generated predominantly from the North Pacific in winter and from a combination of Southern Hemisphere storms and hurricanes in the summer focus on Huntington Beach
column5: creating consistent surf all year long
column6: hence the nickname "Surf City".

column1: The main thoroughfare of Huntington Beach
column3: was originally a cattle route for the main industry of the Rancho. Since its time as a parcel of the enormous Spanish land grant
column4: Huntington Beach has undergone many incarnations. One time it was known as Shell Beach
column5: the town of Smeltzer
column6: and then Gospel Swamp for the revival meetings that were held in the marshland where the community college Golden West College can currently be found. Later it became known as Fairview and then Pacific City
column7: as it developed into a tourist destination. In order to secure access to the Pacific Electric Red Car lines that used to criss-cross Los Angeles and ended in Long Beach
column8: Pacific City ceded enormous power to railroad magnate Henry E. Huntington
column9: and thus became a city whose name has been written into corporate sponsorship
column10: and like much of the history of Southern California

column1: The original Huntington Beach Pier was built in 1904 and was originally a 1
column2: 000-foot-long timber structure. Huntington Beach was incorporated on February 17
column4: during the tenure of its first mayor
column5: Ed Manning. Its original developer was Huntington Beach Company (formerly the West Coast Land and Water Company)
column6: a real-estate development firm owned by Henry Huntington. The Huntington Beach Company is still a major land-owner in the city
column7: and still owns most of the local mineral rights. The company is now wholly owned by the Chevron Corporation.At one time
column8: an encyclopedia company gave away free parcels of land (with the purchase of a whole set for $126) in the Huntington Beach area. The lucky buyers got more than they had bargained for when oil was discovered in the area
column9: and enormous development of the oil reserves followed. Though many of the old reserves are depleted
column10: and the price of land for housing has pushed many of the rigs off the landscape
column11: oil pumps can still be found to dot the city.

column1: Huntington Beach has a borderline semi-arid/Mediterranean climate (Köppen climate classification: BSk/Csb)
column2: gradually changing for the second to the west and south due to its low precipitation. Although areas such as Huntington Central Park and northern Bolsa Chica usually fall into the first climate type
column3: thus being the boundary of the cool summer Mediterranean climate on the west coast of North America
column4: except for elevated portions in the southern end of the state. The climate is generally sunny
column5: dry and cool
column6: although evenings can be excessively damp. In the morning and evening
column7: there are often strong breezes that can reach 15 mph (24 km/h). Ocean water temperatures average 55 °F (13 °C) to 65 °F (18 °C). In the summer
column8: temperatures rarely exceed 85 °F (29 °C). In the winter
column10: even on clear nights. There are about 14 inches (360 mm) of rain
column11: almost all in mid-winter. Frost occurs only rarely
column12: on the coldest winter nights. The area is annually affected by a marine layer caused by the cool air of the Pacific Ocean meeting the warm air over the land. This results in overcast and foggy conditions in May and June.

column1: Construction of any kind on the beach is prohibited without a vote of the people
column2: allowing Huntington Beach to retain its natural connection to the ocean rather than having the view obstructed by residential and commercial developments.

column1: Between Downtown Huntington Beach and Huntington Harbour lies a large marshy wetland
column2: much of which is protected within the Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve. A $110 million restoration of the wetlands was completed in 2006. The reserve is popular with bird watchers and photographers.

column4: which lie across the street from Huntington State Beach
column5: had restoration completed in 2010.The northern and southern beaches (Bolsa Chica State Beach and Huntington State Beach
column6: respectively) are state parks. Only the central beach (Huntington City Beach) is maintained by the city. Camping and RVs are permitted here
column7: and popular campsites for the Fourth of July and the Surfing Championships must be reserved many months in advance. Bolsa Chica State Beach is actually a sand bar fronting the Bolsa Bay and Bolsa Chica State Ecological Reserve.

column1: Huntington Beach sits above a large natural fault structure containing oil. Although the oil is mostly depleted
column2: extraction continues at a slow rate
column3: and still provides significant local income. There are only two off-shore extraction facilities left
column4: however
column5: and the day is not far off when oil production in the city will cease and tourism will replace it as the primary revenue source for resident industry.

Huntington Beach also has the Gothard–Talbert terminus for the Orange County portion of the pipeline running from the Chevron El Segundo refinery.Several hotels have been constructed on the inland side of Pacific Coast Highway (State Route 1) within view of the beach

column1: Huntington Beach contains a major installation of Boeing
column2: formerly McDonnell-Douglas. A number of installations on the Boeing campus were originally constructed to service the Apollo Program
column3: most notably the production of the S-IVB upper stage for the Saturn IB and Saturn V rockets.

column1: While Huntington Beach retains its 15-year trademark of Surf City Huntington Beach
column2: the Huntington Beach Conference and Visitors Bureau filed four applications to register the "Surf City USA" trademark in November 2004. The idea was to market the city by creating an authentic brand based on Southern California's beach culture and active outdoor lifestyle while at the same time creating a family of product licensees who operate like a franchise family producing a revenue stream that could also be dedicated to promoting the brand and city. A ruling by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office released on May 12
column4: awarded three trademark registrations to the Bureau; nine additional trademark registrations have been granted since this time and ten other Surf City USA trademarks are now under consideration. One of the first products the Bureau developed to promote its brand was the Surf City USA Beach Cruiser by Felt Bicycles in 2006. The product has sold out every year in markets worldwide and created demand for a second rental bicycle model that will be marketed to resort locations across the globe starting in 2009. The Bureau now has dozens of other licensed products on the market from Surf City USA soft drinks to clothing to glassware. As of April 2008
column5: the Bureau had more than 20 licensing partners with over 50 different products being prepared to enter the market over the next 18 months. Four of the Bureau's registrations of the trademark are now on the principal register and the remaining ten trademark applications are expected to follow. The Bureau is actively considering registration of the Surf City USA trademark in several different countries and anticipates a growing market for its branded products overseas in coming years.

column1: An ongoing dispute between Huntington Beach and Santa Cruz
column2: California over the trademark garnered national publicity in 2007 when a law firm representing Huntington Beach sent a cease-and-desist letter to a Santa Cruz T-shirt vendor. A settlement was reached in January 2008
column3: which allows the Huntington Beach Conference and Visitors Bureau to retain the trademark.

column4: but the Huntington Beach International Surfing Museum has preserved its memory with ongoing screenings of surfing movies once shown at a Huntington Beach theater and the original metal SURF sign. Another surfing-related attraction in Huntington Beach is the Surfing Walk of Fame.

column1: Huntington Beach hosts car shows such as the Beachcruiser Meet and a Concours d'Elegance. The Beachcruiser Meet is held in March
column2: attracting over 250 classic cars displayed along Main Street and the Pier parking lot. A Concours d'Elegance is held at Central Park in June and benefits the public library. An informal "Donut Derelicts" car show occurs every Saturday morning at the intersection of Adams and Magnolia Street.

column1: Surf City Nights is held every Tuesday night during the year. The Tuesday Surf City Nights is a community-spirited event that features a farmer's market
column4: kiddie rides and a carnival atmosphere. Surf City Nights and the Downtown Huntington Beach Art Walk are presented by the Huntington Beach Downtown Business Improvement District (HBDBID) and the City of Huntington Beach. The Tuesday night Surf City Nights event takes place in the first three blocks of Main Street from Pacific Coast Highway to Orange Avenue.

column1: Huntington Beach is the site of the world surfing championships
column2: held annually in the summer. The city is often referred to as "Surf City" because of this high-profile event
column3: its history and culture of surfing. It is often called the "Surfing Capital of the World"
column4: not for the height of the waves
column5: but rather for the consistent quality of surf.

column1: The city's Ocean View Little League won the 2011 Little League World Series championship
George Freeth was the first person to surf in Huntington Beach with a demonstration on June 20
column2: 1914. Freeth had been demonstrating surfing in southern California as a promotion for the city by Henry E. Huntington. Duke Kahanamoku started surfing in Huntington Beach in 1925 and helped popularize the sport. The first surfboard shop
column3: which was located underneath the Huntington Beach Pier
column4: opened in 1956 by Gordie Duane.Apart from sponsored surf events
column5: Huntington Beach has some of the best surf breaks in the State of California and that of the United States. Huntington Beach has four different facing beaches: Northwest
column6: West
column7: Southwest
column8: and South. Northwest consists of Bolsa Chica State Beach with a length of 3.3 miles (5.3 km)
column9: the West consist of "The Cliffs" or "Dog Beach"
column10: Southwest is considered everything north of the pier which is operated by the City of Huntington Beach. South consists in everything south of the pier which primarily focuses on Huntington State Beach (2.2 Miles)

column1: Bolsa Chica State Beach is operated by the State of California
column3: and the Bolsa Chica State Beach Lifeguards. The beach is very narrow and the sand is very coarse. Bolsa Chica tends to have better surf with NW/W swells during the winter season. During the summer months the beach picks up south/southwest swells at a very steep angle. Due to the bottom of the beach
column4: surf at Bolsa Chica tends to be slowed down and refined to soft shoulders. Longboards are the best option for surfing in the Bolsa Chica area.

column1: The Cliffs or "Dog Beach" is also another popular surf spot. This segment of Huntington Beach is so named because dogs are allowed around the cliff area. Beach is very restricted and often is submerged with high tides. Surf at this location tends to be even bigger than Bolsa Chica during the winter and often better. During the summer most of the South/Southwest swells slide right by and often break poorly. The best option is to take out a longboard
column2: but shortboards will do at times. Dolphins have also been sighted in this area.Just north and south of the Huntington Beach Pier are some well defined sandbars that shift throughout the year with the different swells. Southside of the Pier is often a popular destination during the summer for good surf
column3: but the Northside can be just as well during the winter. Around the Pier it all depends on the swell and the sandbars. Shortboard is your best option for surfing around the Pier.

column2: also known as Huntington State Beach
column3: is where all the south swells impact the coastline. Huntington State Beach is operated by the State of California
column4: Department of Parks & Recreation
column5: and Huntington State Beach Lifeguards. This beach is very wide with plenty of sand. Sandbars dramatically shift during the spring
column6: summer and fall seasons
column7: thus creating excellent surf conditions with a combination South/West/Northwest swell. Due to the Santa Ana River jetties located at the southernmost end of the beach
column8: large sandbars extend across and upcoast
column9: forcing swells to break extremely fast and hollow. Best seasons for surfing at this beach is the summer and fall. The best option for surfing in this area is a shortboard.

column1: Huntington Beach is also a popular destination for kite surfing
column2: and this sport can be viewed on the beach northwest of the pier.

column1: Huntington Beach is the host city of the National Professional Paintball League Super 7 Paintball Championships. The NPPL holds its first event of the year traditionally between the dates of March 23 through March 26.
Huntington Beach also hosts the annual Surf City USA Marathon and Half-Marathon
column2: which is usually held on the first Sunday of February.

column1: Huntington Beach has a large central park
column2: known as Huntington Central Park. Central Park is located between Gothard and Edwards Streets to the east and west
column3: and Slater and Ellis Avenues to the north and south. Dedicated on June 15
column5: Huntington Central Park is the largest city owned park in Orange County with nearly 350 acres (140 ha). The park is vegetated with xeric (low water use) plants
column6: and inhabited by native wildlife. Thick forests encircling the park are supplemented with Australian trees
column7: particularly Blue Gum Eucalyptus
column8: a high water use plant.

column1: The Huntington Beach Public Library is located in Central Park in a notable building designed by Richard Neutra and Dion Neutra. It houses almost a half-million volumes
column3: gift shop and fountains. The library was founded as a Carnegie library in 1914
column4: and has been continuously supported by the city and local activists
column5: with new buildings and active branches at Banning
column6: Oak View
column7: Main Street
column8: and Graham. The library has significant local historical materials and has a special genealogical reference collection. It is independent of the state and county library systems.

column1: The park is also home of Huntington Central Park Equestrian Center
column2: a top class boarding facility that also offers horse rentals to the public
column3: with guided trail rides through the park. There is also a "mud park" available for kids. The world's second oldest disc golf course is available in the park

column6: and the Shipley Nature Center.

column1: Huntington Dog Beach is located in the 1.5-mile (2.4 km) stretch between 21st and Seapoint streets. This is the only area where dogs are allowed on the beach in Huntington Beach. Dog Beach is free to the public. Dog Beach is very popular so visitors should expect the beach and parking lot to be somewhat congested during the summer months and weekends.

The Orange County Register consistently names Huntington Dog Beach as the best dog park in Orange County. Some popular events that take place at Dog Beach are Surf City Surf Dog and So Cal Corgi Nation Beach Days.Preservation Society of Huntington Dog Beach works to keep the beach clean and safe. This 501(c)3 non-profit organization was founded in 1997 and has a five volunteers who serve on the board. The mission statement of the Preservation Society of Huntington Dog Beach
column3: is as follows: "to protect and preserve access to the beach for dogs and their people
column4: as well as to promote responsible dog ownership in order to make our canine companions welcome members of society."The society receives no public financing and relies completely on private donations from dog-lovers who value this public good. This non-profit provides many valuable services that minimize the impact of the negative externalities caused by dog waste and unfriendly dogs which must be addressed in order to protect the environment and keep visitors safe. One of the main reasons dogs are not usually allowed on beaches is that owners do not pick up after them. Doggie waste bags are provided for free (over 3
column5: 000 are used per day during the summer) and dog owners are encouraged to immediately dispose of their dog's waste in one of the many trash cans provided. Additionally
column6: the society organizes a beach cleanup every Sunday where volunteers help clean up trash. To keep visitors safe
column7: aggressive dogs are not allowed and dogs must be kept under control at all times.

column1: The society also creates positive externalities by providing the public with valuable information on their website. This information includes
column4: tips for introducing dogs to the beach for the first time
column5: warnings about the danger of dogs drinking ocean water
column6: and information about nearby RV parking and dog-friendly hotels. Prospective visitors should be aware of the policy regarding leashes: "Under existing city ordinance
column7: dogs must remain leashed. However
column8: for the past several years only unleashed
column9: potentially dangerous dogs have been cited or removed." One important exception is that leashes are always required when entering and exiting the park to ensure safety near PCH.

column1: The Huntington Beach Fire Department provides fire protection and emergency medical services for the city of Huntington Beach
column2: California. In addition to fire services
column3: the HBFD also provides medical transport via a fleet of five ambulances. Each ambulance is staffed by two three-year limited term EMTs and the department transports over 10
column4: 000 patients annually.The Huntington Beach Fire Department was formed as an organization in 1909 with 20 volunteers.  John Tinsley
column5: became the first fire chief. The first fire engine was a 1923 Seagrave purchased in 1922.The Marine Safety Division of the HBFD is responsible for patrolling the 3.5 miles (5.6 km) of shoreline along Huntington Beach and Sunset Beach. The staffing levels vary from just five Marine Safety Officers during the offseason (October to March) to as many as 65 during the summer. The division staffs 30 lifeguard towers along the beach as well as Tower Zero on the Huntington Beach Pier. Members of the Marine Safety division have a wide array of equipment available for their use including 10 Toyota Tacoma patrol trucks
column6: 3 Toyota Tundra patrol trucks
column7: search and rescue SCUBA gear
column8: 3 29-foot Crystaliner twin-engine rescue vessels

column1: Fire protection in Huntington Beach is provided by the Huntington Beach Fire Department. Law enforcement is provided by the Huntington Beach Police Department. Huntington Beach Marine Safety Officers and its seasonal lifeguards are recognized as some of the best in the world with a top-notch safety record. It has an active Community Emergency Response Team training program
column2: that trains citizens as Disaster Service Workers certified by Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) as a part of a free program run by the fire department's Office of Emergency Services.

column1: Emergency services are also provided at State Beach locations. Peace Officers and lifeguards can be found at Bolsa Chica and Huntington State Beach. Such services consist of aquatic rescues
column3: first aid and law enforcement. All services are provided by the State of California
column4: Dept. Parks & Recreation.In 1926
column5: the Santa Ana River dam failed
column6: and flash-flooded its entire delta. The southern oceanic terminus of this delta is now a settled area of Huntington Beach. The distant dam is still functional
column7: but silting up
column8: which is expected to reduce its storage volume
column9: and therefore its effectiveness at flood-prevention. The flood and dam-endangered areas are protected by a levee
column10: but lenders require expensive flood insurance in the delta. There have been serious discussions to eliminate the need for flood insurance and this requirement has already been waived in some areas and may one day no longer be considered a credible threat.

column1: Since it is a seaside city
column2: Huntington Beach has had tsunami warnings
column3: storm surge (its pier has been rebuilt three times)
column4: sewage spills
column5: tornadoes and waterspouts. The cold offshore current prevents hurricanes. The Pier that was rebuilt in the 1990s was engineered to withstand severe storms or earthquakes.

column1: Large fractions of the settled delta are in soil liquefaction zones above known active faults. Most of the local faults are named after city streets.
Many residents (and even city hall) live within sight and sound of active oil extraction and drilling operations. These occasionally spew oil
column2: causing expensive clean-ups. Large parts of the developed land have been contaminated by heavy metals from the water separated from oil.

column1: The local oil has such extreme mercury contamination that metallic mercury is regularly drained from oil pipelines and equipment. Oil operations increase when the price of oil rises. Some oil fields have been approved for development. The worst-polluted areas have been reclaimed as parks. At least one Superfund site
column2: too contaminated to be a park
column3: is at the junction of Magnolia and Hamilton streets
column4: near Edison High School.
